question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Use the definition} of convergence for sequences, prove that

\begin{align*}\lim_{nÂ \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1-2\cos(n)}{n} = 0.\end{align*}
sols:
Here, the limit being 0 means that we simply need to show that given any
$\epsilon >Â 0$ there exists a number $N_\epsilon$ such that

\begin{align*}\left| \frac{1-2\cos(n)}{n} \right| < \epsilon\end{align*} for any value of $n$
larger than $N_\epsilon$.

Since we have that

\begin{align*}-1 \leq \cos(n) \leq 1\end{align*} we can multiply everywhere by -2 and obtain
that

\begin{align*}2 \geq -2\cos(n) \geq -2\end{align*} and add 1 everywhere to obtain

\begin{align*}3 \geq 1-2\cos(n) \geq -1\end{align*} which now allows us to conclude about the
size of $1-2\cos(n)$ in absolute value:

\begin{align*}| 1-2 \cos (n) |Â \leq 3\end{align*}

So we can conclude that

\begin{align*}
\left| \frac{1-2\cos(n)}{n} \right| &= \frac{|1-2\cos(n)|}{n}\\
&\leq \frac{3}{n}\\
&< \epsilon\end{align*}

for any value of $n$ that is larger than $N_\epsilon = 3/\epsilon$; this
concludes our proof.
hints:
As often with trigonometric function, make good use of the fact that

\begin{align*}-1 \leq \cos(x) \leq 1\end{align*} for any value of \emph{x}.
